race.name: Atlas Mountain Race
race.tagline: Moroccan Atlas Mountains ultra-endurance gravel race.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads and tracks through Atlas Mountains. Extreme elevation with mountain and desert scenery. Self-supported ultra-endurance format.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Ultra-endurance adventure race. Extreme Atlas Mountains terrain with very difficult access, high costs, and small field.

biased_opinion.summary: Atlas Mountain Race is an ultra-endurance self-supported race through Morocco—750 miles with 80,000 feet of climbing. The Atlas Mountains are stunning and the adventure is extreme, but the very difficult access, extreme conditions, high costs, and self-supported format keep it in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: An extreme Atlas Mountains ultra-endurance adventure. Worth it for elite ultra-endurance riders with big budgets. Not practical for most riders.

final_verdict.one_liner: Moroccan Atlas Mountains ultra-endurance gravel race.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're an elite ultra-endurance rider with a big budget—maybe. For most riders—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For similar ultra-endurance: Transcontinental Race. For better value: regional gravel races.

logistics.food: Self-supported. Carry all nutrition and resupply in villages.

history.origin_story: Ultra-endurance self-supported race through Atlas Mountains.

course_description.signature_challenge: 750 miles and 80,000 feet through Atlas Mountains.

non_negotiables.why: 750 miles requires months of ultra-endurance preparation.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Moroccan Atlas Mountains ultra-endurance gravel race.

logistics.explanation: Michael Drummond describes "1145km, One thousand, one hundred and forty five kilometres of mystery. The only true 'knowledge' gleaned from select vistas." No published entry fees, airport details, or packet pickup information for Morocco. Race provides GPX tracking and three staffed checkpoints across 750 miles—everything else is self-supported navigation through remote Atlas passes.

length.explanation: Rory Stuart finished in "6 days 4 hours 45 minutes but later reflected: I wholeheartedly think I did pretty darn well. Sure, I could've slept less." At 750 miles, riders average less than 10mph including stops. Justinas Leveika warns "Don't get fooled by 'just' 160 km to the next CP. The average speed in this race is very low."

technicality.explanation: Michael Drummond describes the Telouet Pass descent: "Rocks, boulders and well, more boulders strewn along a convoluted and rarely trodden route that winds down the back of this peak enveloped in thick darkness." Kevin Benkenstein notes "hours spent riding through dry river beds which consist of anything from sand and small stones to baby-head rocks."

elevation.explanation: The 2026 route includes Tizi N'Aït Imi—the highest pass at 2,910m—replacing the iconic Telouet Pass. 80,000 feet of climbing over 750 miles means constant elevation gain through Atlas Mountain crossings. James Hayden experienced "a 10-kilometre climb at 10 percent in 35-degree heat" as his welcome back to the Atlas.

climate.explanation: Jochen Böhringer faced "stiff wind, then heavy rain adds and finally the temperatures drop to 5°C while thunderbolts lighten the dark" followed by flooding that stopped the race. Justinas Leveika experienced "temperatures from -7 to + 25°c" in a single edition. James Hayden notes February brings "0 Celsius at night" despite 30°C daytime temperatures.

altitude.explanation: The new route crosses Tizi N'Aït Imi at 2,910m, the highest pass ever included in AMR. Michael Drummond's Telouet Pass experience at 2,600m involved sustained hike-a-bike: "feet again make connection with terra firma and the bike is used as a cumbersome hiking partner." Multiple high passes require altitude acclimatization while carrying full bikepacking loads.

adventure.explanation: The route explores new M'Goun gorges where "riders will follow a mule trail through the river itself" according to race organizers. Valerio Stuart describes terrain that "looked at times like Utah and at times like Spain" approaching the Cathedral d'Imsfrane rock formation. Michael Drummond encountered sand sections he calls "billions of microscopic permutations of glass with an appetite for tyre and energy."

prestige.explanation: Six years running as part of The Mountain Races series alongside Silk Road and Hellenic Mountain races. Jochen Böhringer found himself "fighting for 3rd place with Philippe Vullioud after Justinas Leveika (1st) and Marin de Saint-Exupéry (2nd)." The February timing attracts serious bikepacking talent, but the field remains smaller than marquee gravel events.

race_quality.explanation: Flooding stopped the 2022 race when "heavy rain dramatically increased the water level of a close-by river to a level that we cannot cross it with our bikes anymore," forcing riders to wait at a gas station. Three checkpoints across 750 miles provides minimal race infrastructure. No published entry fees or detailed race manual suggests organizational gaps.

experience.explanation: Shona and Rich note "The locals are really friendly and often just want a quick chat to know what you're up to and if you like their country. They're normally on a donkey going faster than you are." The Old Colonial Road impressed Jochen Böhringer as "an incredible marvel of engineering" balanced on mountainsides. Pure Atlas Mountain wilderness from Beni-Mellal to the Atlantic.

community.explanation: It attracts the bikepacking crowd more than racers, which creates a weird vibe when some people are touring and others are actually competing. The race might be popular, but it's not building the kind of vocal tribe that defines great gravel events.

field_depth.explanation: When the top three are separated by 40 minutes after 1350km, you're not looking at deep competitive talent. The mix of racing and touring mentalities means half the field is there for the Instagram shots, not the podium. No notable past winners or pro participation mentioned anywhere tells you everything about the competitive level.

value.explanation: Riders get exclusive access to new M'Goun gorge sections and mule trails impossible to replicate privately. Mel Webb's packing challenges—"Standing at 5'2, she's no stranger to the game of tetris that is packing a small bike"—highlight the specialized gear investment required. The adventure justifies costs for those who finish, but international travel and self-sufficiency gear add up quickly.

expenses.explanation: Morocco isn't cheap to reach, and when you factor in international flights, gear for desert crossings, GPS tracker rental, and eight days of complete self-sufficiency, you're looking at serious money. The race won't even publish entry fees, which usually means they're embarrassed by the number. Add in the risk of expensive gear failure in remote Atlas passes and this becomes a rich person's adventure.
